ygData.subject: Re: Advice to NEAT beginner
ygData.msgSnippet: Ken, Thanks for the good advice. My idea to implement a delay in the firing of a node is simply to allow NEAT to insert a special node type with a single input

Ken,

Thanks for the good advice.

My idea to implement a delay in the firi=
ng of a node is 
simply to allow NEAT to insert a special node type with a =

single input & output. No transfer function. Effect is just to delay a
nod=
e update by one firing cycle.
Does that feel like a reasonable approach to =
implementing
an evolvable time delay?

Mike



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Here's a few pointers:
> 
> -D=
ebug every function as soon as you create it.  For exampe, when 
> you writ=
e mutate_add_node, apply it to some dummy genomes and make 
> sure it reall=
y works.  Doing this will save you a lot of debugging 
> time at the end, b=
ecause if you only start debugging after the whole 
> thing is created it w=
ill be very difficult to tease apart all the 
> interlocking parts to find =
what's causing a bug.
> 
> -Memory leaks can happen in C++ with all the dyn=
amic memory 
> allocation (and cleanup) that NEAT requires so be careful.
>=
 
> -To test yout system when it's complete, use XOR.  It's not a very 
> i=
nteresting experiment, but it usually catches major problems, like 
> way o=
ff parameterizations and things like that.  And it ensures that 
> you can =
evolve structure since it requires a single hidden node to 
> evolve.
> 
> =
ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "aimike002" <aimike002@> wrote:
> >
>=
 > Hi I'm fairly new to NEAT. I'm thinking of writing my own NEAT
> > imple=
mentation from scratch, rather than modify one of the existing
> > releases=
. The main reasons are fisrtly, to improve my understanding
> > and secondl=
y to give me the flexibility to add any extra bits I 
> feel
> > might be i=
nteresting.
> > Based on some suggestions posted here, I hope to include so=
me form 
> of
> > time delay as well as the ability to use a range of diffe=
rent 
> transfer
> > functions.
> > 
> > It's probably going to be written =
in C++ under MS windows. My 
> interest
> > at the moment is oriented to ap=
plying NEAT to analysis of noisy 
> time
> > series data.
> > 
> > Would ap=
preciate any suggestions, pitfalls, feature-wishes, lessons
> > learnt etc,=
 that may be useful for me to know in advance in this. 
> > 
> > Mike
> >
>=
